comments.commentBody: Well, most of that is patently false, but your lies reveal a truth nonetheless:  we can all thank god that Republicans have stood fast against the President's malfeasance.

Beautifully stated, and far more eloquent and insightful than the column to which you are responding. You have posted a lot of excellent comments, but this might be your very best.

Why not call what the GOP and their plutocratic companions have cooked up to destroy Obama what it is? Treason, which in the Orwellian world of Faux News and things go better with Koch is called Patriotism

I think when Thirteen Days in September the story of the Camp David Accords becomes more widely read we will have a better understanding of how Carter was shafted by all sides. As a Zionist, the son of a Zionist and the grandson of a Zionist I am particularly humbled by the Israel can do no wrong lobby without whose lies and duplicity we may have seen Israel take its proper role in the middle east leading to the successful replacement of vicious despots with democracy. Carter had no friends anywhere at least Obama still has a following.

You overlooked one thing, Lord Bruni - GOP sedition.

America's modern right-wing propaganda-industrial-complex is something the first world has not seen since Joseph Goebbels whipped Germany over a psychopathic cliff a few years back.

President Obama is a good 'moderate Republican' President and deserves high praise for reforming healthcare, rebuilding a shattered economy, raising taxes, and maintaining his impeccable personal dignity.

But never has any American President faced such orchestrated sedition by the opposition party, their donors and the fake media.

Never have so many lies been propagandized about a President.

Never has so much disinformation been broadcasted as fact and malfeasance perpetuated as has been done by the Republicans and GOP apparatchik.

-The President was not born in America.

-The President is a Muslim.

-Universal healthcare will destroy the nation.

-Benghazi Derangement Syndrome.

-Trickle-down economics.

-Climate change and evolution are hoaxes.

-Blocking judicial appointees left and right.

-Disabling the Senate with the filibuster.

-Employing the 'Majority of the Majority' Rule to disable the House.

- Dog-whistling poorly educated voters to rally their latent racism and spite for the first black President.

This is the collective work of Republican psychopaths, not a political party.

This is a real GOP political conspiracy to destroy the nation.

In light of this disgraceful GOP backlighting, President Obama is simply spectacular.

Americans like Nick are right to be pessimistic. No one at all has offered anything like a rational, convincing strategy for defeating jihad, starting with ISIS. And who can doubt that if we can't "cure" this "cancer," it will kill us by eventually getting one of Pakistan's hundreds of nukes into beautiful downtown Manhattan, not to mention Tel Aviv?

A president searching for a legacy; any legacy, an armed forces searching for a purpose; any purpose, a defense industry searching for profits; any profits and political hawks search for a victory; any victory.

General Dempsey may be speaking for himself or said in public which has been discussed behind closed doors in the White house and the Pentagon. Regardless, this is more than a "slippery slope', but an avalanche.

Australian media has reported, several days ago, they were not only contributing air support, but also special forces ground troops. Seems to me, that the us made the same commitment; though the American people were told otherwise; until today.

Pope Frances may be right; he world is heading for anew world war. Even worse, it looks like between he US coalition, various Arab and Persian (yes Iran is in this) states, and ISIS/ISIL they may get their wish, making Pope FRancis more right each day. the Russians and/or Chinese decide to get involved (support ISIS/ISIL) then you have a world war on your hands.

Sound crazy?Well, 100 years ago no one expected hat he assassination of Archducke Ferdinand would set into motion WWI. Nor, did anyone expect that four years later that WWI's winners would carve up the Ottoman Empire and set into motion 100 years of middle east instability that eventually led to the rise of ISIS/ISIL and others.

No one can predict the future, but if history is any guide, it looks like this is going to be a long battle with a bleak outcome.

Is it wrong to look at the historical roots of the problems we now face? If people were not considering what had led to the creation of ISIS, then they could be accused of being blind to fact.

I am not a heavily partisan supporter of Mr. Obama or any president, for that matter. I fully recognize that part of the current "American disease" is a willingness on both sides, or all sides, to turn every problem into a partisan attack point against the other. Still, count me as one hesitant to call down the President at every turn. There were people ready to call this a failed presidency after the 2010 elections when 100s of millions in outside help turned over the House to Republicans.

I am not cheerful or sanguine about the next two years and four months or so of this White House. He, and they, need a reboot and a massive rethink and, odds on, he and they aren't going to do either one. The aides have always been too confident that he can interview his way out of any problem. They know they have a thoroughbred race horse and they want him out there on the track. Now, it is causing more trouble than benefit.

Okay, more. Obama came in with big potential but without sufficient follow through. They failed to grasp the virulence of the opposition and the new tactics of propaganda and rumor being employed.

There is still time. The "presidential moment" might yet provide the chance to recalibrate expectations and to finish much stronger. I think. I hope.

http://terryreport.com

I  have a patient who is newly insured through Obamacare ,diagnosed with diabetes and is now on medication.  She is angry because the President is making her take a lot of pills now. People would shrug at their lack of insurance and now rail that we are forcing them to avoid strokes and amputations.  The biggest failing may have been to market it as heathcare reform when it was really insurance reform.  It will take a few years for it to sink in that healthcare makes us healthier.
President Obama was elected two times by the citizens of this country.

How did the obstructionism of the Republicans impact the ACA when the Democrats had majorities sufficient to pass the bill in both houses?  It has to be Democrats who defected who caused whatever deficiencies are in the bill - not Republicans.

Yeah, it sounds like the conservative dream isn't  playing out very well in Kansas! I've often though we should divide America into a liberal state and a conservative one. All the conservatives would try to cross the border as soon as any misfortune befell them. Conservatives have no problem at all with handouts as long as they are for them and other people they deem worthy like them.

I am reminded of polling regarding George W. Bush.  Repeatedly Americans said that they disagreed with his every position.  Then they said they were going to vote for him because they "trusted" him.  To do what?  Work for legislation you're going to hate?  We need a return to critical thinking skills.  We also need to acknowledge that a huge number of Americans are still racist to the core.
Excellent thoughtful article on difficult subject. People are concerned about the economy more than the ACA at this point.

The current insurance monopoly of forcing people to pay twice, once monthly (premium) then again after service (co-pay) is nuts.  Put all the costs on the table for everyone to see in advance, let market competitiveness work it's magic or set up a commission like a utility to set prices universally.  The cost of the same procedure shouldn't be wildly different from one hospital to the next in the same town.
They don't believe that either.

Hi Adrian - I consider myself a reasonably smart person and I had not heard of this concept before reading the article. I found it enlightening and even without knowing the term many of us are familiar with the real world implications.

I for one will now walk away from crappy food rather than eat it no matter the cost.

It's hard for a kid to get a new toy and not open it, ask Andy Stizer.

> we broke Iraq...
> No it is not really our war.

OK, in your first sentence you admit breaking Iraq. Then you dissolve yourself of any responsibility for fixing it. And you will generously allow limited airstrikes. So charitable of you, thank you.

Since we broke Iraq for the wrong reasons, I do not mind some limited activity to try to restrict the slaughter of people by fanatics but now we are thinking about slipping back into that mess(there are other terms). No it is not really our war. Yes try to throttle IS(iis,isil) back but it is up to the people in that region to decide their fate in large part. IS is part of a history that began a thousand years ago. So no NO MORE TROOPS.

Seriously? RG3 was an Olympic caliber 400 hurdler in high school. He was invited to the Olympic trials in our country's best track and field event.

His first year in the NFL he could outrun the best defensive backs. Now that he's suffered devastating knee injuries it's a different story. The ankle dislocation is a huge blow as well.

I doubt that Danny could bear the sight of RG3 doing really well for another team (Remember Brad Johnson, who went to Tampa Bay and won the Super Bowl?). RG3 is likely to play for Washington until he's no longer able to play well. A huge shame.
Invest in getting voters registered and too the polls.

It isn't obvious to most people and it is generally ignored even by those who know it, whether it involves putting more money in repairing a bad car because "we've put so much into repairing it already" or whether it is any of a number of American Presidents unable to pull out of idiotic overseas commitments on the grounds that "too many have died in this fight".
Let's not mix up our economic theory.  This is a case of "buyers remorse" (plus denial) rather than "sunk cost fallacy."

Tarajunky - don't be silly.  The medicare money is the inappropriate subsidy for insurers to induce them to offer the fraudulent medicare advantage programs.  Now the subsidized takers can pay the full fare.

Flipping the Senate is an objective at least some Republicans seem as plausible -- not that it's likely that they'd do well enough in both houses to override a veto, but they'll still fight over it.

The important question is why people pay any attention to 30-second spots when it should be fairly clear that

(1) they're almost always from interested parties,
(2) they can be quite deliberately deceptive, and
(3) even if they're being truly honest and well-intentioned, 30 seconds is a terribly short time to convey anything of substance.
They are depending upon the ignorance of the people,and rightly so.

I just find it unfathomable "Interest groups and candidates, including Mr. McConnell, have run more than 10,000 broadcast television spots here since January 2013 that mention the law in a negative way, according to Kantar Media’s Campaign Media Analysis Group. " That would 623 days as of today, that would be like 16-17 ads a day. Talk about wasteful spending and we are just finishing primary season and heading into full tilt election season. This being a midterm election to boot!? I cannot imagine the cost the television owners must be happy.
All financial decisions are marginal decisions.

It's a canard that Bush was responsible for the poor Katrina response.  It was the epic endemic New Orleans corruption (Nagin just went to jail) and the refusal to take suggestions ahead of the storm (they didn't get on the buses out of there or allow the food caches to be distributed around outside the center of the city).    This was repeated on The View just today, that Bush was bad because he surveyed the devastation from the plane.  Really?    What was he supposed to do?  That was done only at the beginning and he did personally appear in New Orleans and on the ground there.

100% correct, Josh. The one-year-old Nexus 5 is a wonderful phone at 5", with great software and hardware - and guess what, better specs in many ways than the newest iPhones. @scsmits and @RAPinkus - if you think the newest Android is "rough" or that Andriod has focused on things like "touching phones" you've really missed some good things.

But best of all, the Nexus 5 (available in the Google Play Store) is $300 less expensive than the iPhone 6.

I'm amazed when I see people with an iPhone today. How do they even see anything on that tiny screen? No periods or commas on the keyboard? No swipe keyboard option (factory)? Who even uses a keyboard anymore, anyways? You should see the iPhone users frown when I use voice-control on my Nexus 5... "Oh, Siri doesn't do that."

An iPhone seems like something for people ages 50 and above. Oh wow, now can you pay with your phone! Android users have been doing that for years.

And the new iPhone 6.... seriously only 4.7"? That's the same size as the LG Optimus L90, which is only $50 through T-Mobile and feels somewhat sophomoric and small. In today's world, the ideal size is 5" or a hair above. You really do lose a lot in that 1/3 of an inch.

In summary, if we are all 20 year old's starting our junior year in college, the iPhone is like a middle-of-Pennsylvania high school quarterback whose popularity and fortune has fallen fairly quickly in the last couple years. Those were the good old days, huh?
Time to get rid of my 9 month old phone and pick up one of these magical devices. Isn't this what living is all about? No wonder it's on the front page...this changes everything!
Well maybe broken windows policing is one of the major reasons for the decline in crime!
Some of us have lives and don't want to spend them tinkering with kludgy Android interfaces.  I want my phone to work like my refrigerator.  Door open, light on. Door closed, light off.
